questionText: High heels were originally worn by men, not women.
The little black dress was popularized by Coco Chanel.
Jeans were first created as durable work pants for miners.
Sneakers got their name because they made people louder when walking.
Gucci is an Italian luxury brand, not a type of sandwich.
The word ‘denim’ comes from the French phrase ‘serge de Nîmes’.
The fedora was originally designed for women before men adopted it.
Nike was named after the Greek goddess of victory.
Paris is often called the fashion capital of the world.
Crocs were first designed as boating shoes, not fashion statements.
The term ‘haute couture’ refers to high-end custom-fitted fashion.
Flip-flops were originally inspired by Japanese sandals called zōri.
The first fashion magazine was published in France in the 17th century.
Sunglasses were invented in ancient China to hide poker faces.
The tuxedo is named after a place in New York called Tuxedo Park.
Louis Vuitton started as a luggage company, not handbags.
Plaid originated in Scotland, not from picnic tablecloths.
Adidas was founded by two brothers who later split, one founding Puma.
The beret is strongly associated with French culture.
The first pair of Ray-Ban sunglasses were made for pilots.
The miniskirt was a big trend in the 1960s.
Velcro was invented by accident while studying burrs on clothing.
The brand Zara originated in Spain.
Tie-dye became a symbol of hippie culture in the 1960s.
The bow tie was inspired by Croatian mercenaries.
Birkenstocks were originally designed as orthopedic shoes.
The first fashion week was held in New York, not Paris.
The hoodie became popular as casual wear in the 1970s.
The kimono is a traditional garment of Japan.
Converse Chuck Taylors were first made as basketball shoes.
The color black is often considered slimming in fashion.
The sari is a traditional garment worn in India.
Ugg boots originated in Australia.
Denim jackets were first designed as tuxedos.
The Panama hat actually comes from Ecuador.
Hermès is famous for luxury bags and scarves.
The trench coat was originally designed for soldiers in WWI.
Denim jeans became globally famous thanks to Levi Strauss.
H&M stands for Hennes & Mauritz.
The fashion brand Prada was founded in Italy.
Fashion models walk the runway in reverse during fashion week.
Alexander McQueen was known for his dramatic runway shows.
Versace’s logo features the head of Medusa.
The term 'boho' refers to bohemian fashion style.
Runways are always circular in shape.
The term 'retro' means inspired by styles from the past.
Tommy Hilfiger is an American fashion brand.
A fashion faux pas means a mistake in dressing.
Dior is a French luxury fashion house.
Zippers were originally called 'clasp lockers'.
The bowler hat was originally designed to protect gamekeepers’ heads from low-hanging branches.
Platform shoes were once worn to elevate the height of wealthy Venetian men.
The cravat is the ancestor of the modern necktie.
High heels were banned in France during the French Revolution.
The first printed fashion magazine was launched in Germany in 1586.
The kimono literally means 'thing to wear' in Japanese.
The miniskirt was invented by French designer André Courrèges.
The corset was once considered a health-promoting garment.
The famous tartan patterns were worn by Scottish clans as uniforms.
Chanel No. 5 is named after Coco Chanel’s favorite number.
The trench coat’s buttons were designed to hold gloves.
The term 'peacoat' comes from the Dutch word 'pije', meaning a type of cloth.
Denim originally meant 'from Nîmes' in France.
The fedora hat got popular after being featured in gangster movies of the 1920s.
The pencil skirt was named for its straight, narrow shape, like a pencil.
The bow tie is a variation of the cravat.
The camisole originally referred to a type of jacket worn over a dress.
Ugg boots became a global trend when celebrities started wearing them.
The peplum is a short overskirt attached to a blouse or jacket.
The trench coat is considered unisex fashion today.
Hoodies were first worn by laborers to protect from cold and rain.
The peacoat was worn by sailors in the navy.
Fashion week is held in four major cities: New York, London, Milan, and Paris.
The brand Fendi is best known for its handbags and fur.
Tie-dye is traditionally a Japanese technique called Shibori.
The term 'capsule wardrobe' refers to a collection of timeless clothes.
The beret is often associated with artists and French culture.
Platform shoes were a 1970s disco trend.
The little black dress is considered a wardrobe staple.
Sneakers are also called trainers in the UK.
The leather jacket became iconic thanks to James Dean.
High heels can make the wearer appear taller and change posture.
The kimono has wide sleeves and is wrapped left over right.
Levi’s 501 jeans were originally made for miners and workers.
The corset is now mostly used for fashion rather than waist training.
Plaid shirts were originally made for Scottish tartans.
Sneakers can be worn for sports or as casual fashion.
The beret can be worn tilted to the side for style.
Hats were once mandatory in many social events for women.
The trench coat became a fashion icon after World War I.
The peplum accentuates the waist and adds flair to a blouse.
Adidas’ three stripes were originally added for shoe stability, not style.
Platform shoes were first worn in the 15th century in Venice.
Chanel introduced costume jewelry to make fashion more accessible.
The iconic red sole shoes belong to Christian Louboutin.
The stiletto heel was named after a dagger, not a fancy Italian dessert.
The fedora became a gangster icon thanks to Al Capone movies.
Vivienne Westwood is credited with bringing punk fashion to the mainstream.
Balenciaga once designed shoes that were intentionally too high to make walking an extreme sport.
The maxi skirt became popular during the hippie era of the 1960s and 70s.
The skinny jeans trend was inspired by the 1980s rockers.
Goth fashion often incorporates Victorian-era clothing and accessories.
High-top sneakers were originally worn by basketball players to protect ankles.
The jumpsuit was popularized by Elvis Presley in the 1970s.
Tie-dye wasn’t invented in the 1960s; it dates back to ancient India and Japan.
The loafer shoe was inspired by Norwegian farmers’ casual footwear.
Ripped jeans were once considered a symbol of rebellion.
The bomber jacket was originally designed for military pilots during World War II.
The puffer jacket was inspired by life jackets and padded outdoor gear.
Platform sneakers became a global trend in the 1990s, thanks to pop stars.
The beret was adopted by military forces as part of their uniform.
The cargo pants trend comes from military workwear.
The jumpsuit is now a staple in both casual and formal fashion.
The kimono-inspired fashion trend appeared in Western fashion during the 1970s.
The trench coat was adopted by fashion designers like Burberry and became iconic.
The peplum trend has appeared multiple times throughout fashion history.
The brand Gucci was founded in 1921 by Guccio Gucci in Florence, Italy.
The maxi dress trend returned in the 2000s as a comfortable yet stylish choice.
The cargo jacket has been used both in fashion and for practicality.
The pencil skirt was named for its slim, straight silhouette, not because you write with it.
The turtleneck became famous in the 20th century as a symbol of intellectual fashion.
The fedora hat experienced a comeback thanks to indie movies in the 2000s.
The corset has been adapted into modern fashion as a stylish outerwear piece.
Plaid skirts are traditionally associated with school uniforms in some countries.
The trench coat was once worn by explorers and detectives in novels and movies.
The bow tie has been associated with both formal fashion and quirky style.
The poncho is a traditional South American garment adapted into fashion.
Denim skirts and jackets became a symbol of youth rebellion in the 1970s.
Platform shoes are both fashionable and challenging to walk in.
Harem pants are inspired by Middle Eastern traditional clothing.
The kimono-inspired robe trend became popular in Western fashion magazines.
Bohemian fashion combines eclectic, vintage, and ethnic elements.
The bomber jacket trend is often revived in streetwear fashion.
Chunky sneakers became a trend in the 2010s, inspired by 1990s fashion.
The fashion industry has embraced sustainability through eco-friendly fabrics.
The beret has been worn by artists, soldiers, and fashion enthusiasts alike.
The little black dress remains a timeless wardrobe staple.
Trench coats are often styled with belts to accentuate the waist.
Hoodies are now worn in both casual and high-fashion contexts.
The jumpsuit has become a versatile choice for both men and women.
Cropped jackets became trendy as a stylish alternative to long coats.
The cloche hat was a fashion staple during the 1920s flapper era.
The double-breasted suit adds a formal and sophisticated look.
The athleisure trend blends sportswear with everyday fashion.
Peacoats often have a double row of buttons for a classic naval style.
The cape has made comebacks in both superhero costumes and high fashion.
The flared pants trend returned in the 2010s from 1970s fashion.
The peplum top can make your waist appear slimmer and more defined.
The cargo pants revival in streetwear added more pockets for convenience.
Fashion influencers often mix vintage and modern clothing for unique looks.
Animal prints have been used in fashion to convey boldness and confidence.
The fashion trend called 'normcore' celebrates simple, everyday clothing.
Leather jackets are considered timeless wardrobe staples.
The high-low hemline creates a dramatic effect in dresses and skirts.
Chunky boots have become popular in both streetwear and runway shows.
The color blocking trend mixes bold, contrasting colors in one outfit.
Harem pants are baggy at the top but taper towards the ankle.
The tunic is a loose-fitting top often inspired by traditional garments.
The bomber jacket has been adapted in luxury fashion collections.
Wide-leg trousers are both fashionable and comfortable.
The fashion term 'statement piece' refers to bold items that stand out.
The cargo jacket is versatile for both fashion and utility.
The scarf has been used as a fashion accessory, a headwrap, and even a belt.
The statement necklace trend can instantly elevate a simple outfit.
Culottes are pants that resemble a skirt but have separate legs.
Bell sleeves add drama and elegance to tops and dresses.
The turtleneck trend has made comebacks in winter collections over decades.
The bucket hat was originally used for fishing before becoming a fashion trend.
The kimono robe trend is often seen in boho-chic fashion.
The athleisure trend allows gym clothes to be worn outside the gym.
The midi skirt length is between the knee and ankle, versatile for day or night wear.
The trench coat’s epaulets were originally designed to hold gloves or rank insignia.
The fashion term 'capsule wardrobe' emphasizes minimalism and timeless pieces.
The oversized blazer trend combines comfort with bold fashion statements.
The corset-inspired tops are often worn as outerwear in modern fashion.
Chokers were popular in the 1990s and made a comeback in the 2010s.
The houndstooth pattern is often used in jackets, skirts, and suits.
The culottes trend allows freedom of movement while looking fashionable.
The trench coat has remained a timeless fashion item for decades.
The bohemian style often incorporates flowy fabrics and ethnic patterns.
Statement sleeves like puffed or bell sleeves draw attention to the arms.
The crop top trend has been revived in different decades from the 1980s onward.
Platform sandals became a summer trend inspired by 1970s fashion.
Wide-leg pants can create a dramatic and elegant silhouette.
The oversized hoodie trend mixes comfort with streetwear style.
Alexander McQueen once staged a fashion show with robots walking the runway.
The high-fashion 'airbag dress' was designed to inflate upon impact.
Punk fashion originally included safety pins as a statement against conventional style.
The fashion term 'haute couture' refers to custom-fitted, high-end clothing.
Maison Margiela once showed a runway with models wearing literal paper dresses.
The famous Met Gala themes often influence global fashion trends for months.
The fashion technique called 'bias cut' allows dresses to cling elegantly to curves.
Iris van Herpen is known for combining technology and fashion in her designs.
The bubble dress was a revolutionary silhouette created by Pierre Cardin.
Fashion designer Rei Kawakubo once sent models down a runway covered in garbage-inspired clothes.
The 'trench dress' is a reinterpretation of the classic trench coat for women.
Maison Margiela has a famous collection featuring deconstructed garments.
The concept of 'fashion phygital' blends physical and digital fashion experiences.
The crinoline was a stiffened or structured petticoat designed to hold out a skirt.
The avant-garde fashion movement often defies conventional wearability.
Iris Apfel is famous for her oversized glasses and bold accessories.
The fashion term 'silueta trapecio' refers to a trapeze-shaped dress from the 1950s.
Balmain's intricate embroidery often takes hundreds of hours to complete by hand.
Fashion designer Issey Miyake is known for pleated designs that never wrinkle.
The exaggerated shoulder pads trend of the 1980s symbolized power dressing.
The peplum trend was originally inspired by traditional armor flaps.
Maison Margiela once created a collection entirely using recycled garments.
The fashion term 'sartorial' refers to anything related to tailoring or clothing.
The hoop skirt was a revolutionary fashion innovation in the 19th century.
Iris van Herpen integrates 3D printing into her couture dresses.
Alexander McQueen's 'plato’s Atlantis' collection used digital prints inspired by marine life.
The fashion term 'avant-garde' literally means 'ahead of the guard'.
The hobble skirt of the 1910s restricted stride to create a dramatic look.
The fashion technique of 'draping' involves arranging fabric on a mannequin.
Jean-Paul Gaultier famously designed the cone bra for Madonna’s tour.
The fashion term 'peau de soie' refers to a type of satin fabric with a soft luster.
The 'bubble skirt' silhouette creates a voluminous effect at the hemline.
Futuristic fashion often incorporates metallic fabrics and exaggerated shapes.
The fashion term 'haute joaillerie' refers to high-end, luxury jewelry.
The 'sack dress' of the 1920s rejected the corset and embraced a looser silhouette.
The architectural approach in fashion focuses on structured, sculptural garments.
The fashion term 'gabardine' refers to a tightly woven, durable fabric.
The kimono sleeve in high fashion can be both dramatic and functional.
The 'balloon sleeve' adds volume and theatrical flair to tops and dresses.
The fashion term 'couture' literally means 'sewing' in French.
The fashion house Schiaparelli was famous for surrealist designs inspired by art.
The taffeta fabric is crisp and smooth, often used for evening gowns.
Avant-garde fashion challenges conventional ideas of beauty and wearability.
The 'Peacock dress' motif often symbolizes extravagance and luxury in fashion.
Fashion futurism experiments with unconventional materials like plastics and metals.
The fashion term 'organza' refers to a thin, sheer, plain weave fabric used in evening wear.
The bustle of the 19th century added dramatic volume to the back of women’s skirts.
The fashion term 'trompe-l'oeil' involves visual illusions in clothing design.
The fashion house Dior introduced the 'New Look' in 1947, reviving femininity post-war.
Crystals and sequins are used in haute couture to catch light dramatically on the runway.
The fashion term 'bouclé' refers to a yarn or fabric with looped texture.
The fashion term 'mille-feuille' inspired layered skirt designs reminiscent of pastry.
The fashion designer Elsa Schiaparelli once collaborated with Salvador Dalí for surreal designs.
The 'hobble skirt' restricted walking stride intentionally for dramatic effect.
The fashion term 'gossamer' refers to extremely fine and delicate fabric.
The fashion term 'appliqué' involves sewing decorative pieces of fabric onto garments.
The avant-garde designer Comme des Garçons is known for asymmetrical, conceptual fashion.
The fashion term 'brocade' refers to richly decorative shuttle-woven fabrics with raised patterns.
The 'bias cut' technique was pioneered by Madeleine Vionnet for fluid, curve-hugging gowns.
Fashion designers sometimes use 'toile' to create a prototype garment before the final version.
The 'mermaid dress' is fitted to the body and flares dramatically near the knees.
The fashion term 'smocking' refers to decorative gathering of fabric with embroidery stitches.
The fashion term 'batik' refers to a technique of wax-resist dyeing applied to cloth.
Fashion designers sometimes create garments inspired by architecture and sculpture.
The fashion term 'fascinator' refers to a small decorative headpiece often worn at events.
The 'ruffle' design element can appear on sleeves, skirts, and collars for dramatic flair.
The fashion term 'bias tape' refers to fabric strips cut on the bias for flexible edging.
The fashion term 'peau d’ange' refers to ultra-soft, delicate fabrics.
The fashion term 'dolman sleeve' is wide at the armhole and narrow at the wrist.
The 'tutu' originated in ballet but has inspired high-fashion skirt designs.
The 'caplet' in fashion is a small cape covering the shoulders for style and warmth.
Fashion designers use draping mannequins to perfect fabric flow before sewing.
The fashion term 'coutil' refers to a strong cotton or linen fabric used in corsets.
The fashion term 'peignoir' refers to a sheer, flowing dressing gown.
The 'ball gown' silhouette is designed for maximum drama and volume on the skirt.
The 'sailor collar' became a fashion icon inspired by naval uniforms.
Fashion designers sometimes create garments inspired by historical armor.
The 'harem pants' silhouette was adapted into high fashion from Middle Eastern attire.
The 'crinoline' cage skirt allowed skirts to expand without excessive fabric weight.
The 'peplum jacket' adds a flared waistline inspired by 19th-century fashion.
The fashion term 'moire' refers to fabric with a rippled, water-like appearance.
The 'slip dress' trend of the 1990s was inspired by lingerie.
The 'asymmetrical hemline' adds a modern, edgy look to skirts and dresses.
The fashion term 'batiste' refers to a fine, lightweight fabric used for delicate garments.
The 'capelet' is a tiny cape used in haute couture for layering elegance.
The 'smocking' technique allows fabric to stretch while adding texture.
Fashion designers sometimes experiment with LED lights to create glowing garments.
The 'jacquard' weaving technique allows complex patterns to be woven into fabric.
The 'draped gown' emphasizes flowing fabric and elegant silhouettes.
The 'pleated skirt' was popularized by Coco Chanel as a sporty-chic look.
